cons: Extremely low pay. Complete hold on raises since COVID, no indication of when they will return. Only a small 1-2% raise during normal times, partially based on merit. Very greedy central administration that is not committed to academia. No transparency.

college students in general

pros: Awesome community, engaging research, funding for conferences, amazing benefits (the healthcare is top-notch, vacation days and holidays, ample sick time, employer matching HSA/retirement, PSLF-qualified employer, FREE TUITION for continuing education and children). Lots of learning opportunities.
cons: I think some labs have better community than others, so I may be particularly lucky. Talk with people who would be your co-workers to see if they like their specific department/lab. Due to the budget overall post-pandemic, there may be staff pay/benefits cuts, which is part of the reason that staff are forming a union - currently, staff have no collective bargaining and pay/benefit cuts are carried out with no negotiation.

review_title: Who's the Most Crooked Of All?
pros:
Vermont is by far one of the most beautiful states in the country. I have been everywhere! 
College students are so eager and happy to be here.
cons:
This university does not operate with any principles. It is shocking. They also have too much power as they own the hospital. No one questions them no matter what they do!
As an accountant, I found this very disturbing when the college does NOT pay its own bills .It hires contractors and small businesses, works them like dogs and does not pay its bills. Lawyers threaten constantly. I was shocked and asked about it and got reprimanded. Very political atmosphere, people are promoted on who they know rather than actual talent. There are good staff at this university - small bunch but they are not appreciated and the majority are lazy, cruising by and insanely incompetent.

I do NOT recommend this college in ANY WAY.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros:
- Free Tuition plus stipend
- 20 hrs a week
cons:
- Work varies between class
- Depends on professor you are assigned to

pros:
Intentional diversity and social justice education and conversation both in division and department (Dept. is more intimate and purposeful)
Pay is pretty competitive in Northeast.
Housing is open to pets (live-on staff). Lease agreement is in good faith so don’t abuse it.
There’s support to continue your education while working.
Dental and health care are great. Fairly easy to access specialty medicine unlike other places in the US. Child care is challenging in Vermont, however.
If you like to have just about all your need to live somewhere long term, love co-op grocery experience, and smaller city Burlington is really ideal. 
Mountains are 30 to 45 minutes away and there’s more ski lodges 1 to 3 hours away if you’re looking for a true get away.
Vermont is a very conscious state on wildlife and nature; the air is clean and fresh and people’s re genuinely happy to live there long term.
Many mini conferences that are free to staff including professional development series to attend and present at.
Opportunities to gain professional development via funding by scholarships or from the department.
cons:
‘Committees’ are hand picked; it’s about who you know, what you know, and ultimately someone nominating you. If your supervisor and you are not on good terms/ they see you as less than adequate, forget about joining any committees other the run of the mill regular committees. 
No level between Assistant Director and Area Coordinator AKA you’re an Residence Director (no supervision of entry level staff, just grads) so the jump to supervision of professional staff is quite large. 
Most staff only stay 1 to 2 years and large turn over leaves large gaps to both train and prep new staff. Trouble recruiting somewhat and retaining
Strong emphasis on white fragility; white people taking space to talk about their guilt and pain and basically speak on their experiences sometimes speaking for people of color. They do well to minimize the damage but still draining 
Staff looks monochromatic; There’s a ton of white people, some black and brown staff. Sprinkles of Latinx and API if any. There is an problem in recruiting and retaining API and Latina staff. Don’t expect a lot of support or to see people like you (maybe 1 to 2). You have to create the community.
Vermont is heavily ableist and masculine driven due to the ‘conquering’ nature of the outdoors and athletic landscape; There’s a level of acceptance that happens but it waivers. Masculine ideals will be impressed on you by POC, by white men, and by cis people especially. 
Trans people, especially POC, finding people like you is nearly impossible. One identity will be there but it will be white trans/non-binary and that’s not the same. 
Although Vermont is a good place to live long term UVM may not be ideal. It’s is fast paced and demanding. The students are 90% white and very well off financially (some saying the don’t care about what disaster the custodial staff clean up). The few students of color are tired and stretched thin facing racism in the classroom and all over campus.
There’s confusion on allowing staff to seek career opportunities outside of different departments. On one hand, it’s baseline supportive (i.e. references, good luck, etc.). It varies from supervisor there’s some improvement but it’s still sketchy.

job_title: Medical Assistant II in South Burlington, VT
pros: Great 403b with 3% match. FSA & HRA options. Decent health care plans to choose from. Depending on where you work, some departments have a real family vibe between employees. Taking time off is usually accommodated easily.
cons: Clinical staff is severely under staffed at all times- hence the nurse strike. Management is like a revolving door, yet their salaries thrive as they climb the corporate ladder. Clinical staff (below providers) do not get bonuses or yearly cost of living wage increases. They get a very small yearly percentage increase. Ultimately, that means you make less money the longer you stay. If it wasn't for the benefits then it wouldn't be worth the loss.

pros:
the work at UVM-CVPH is rewarding
there is a lot of work to do
it is very fast paced
you can meet some really nice people
the in house credit union is awesome
the in house vendors are pretty sweet too
UVM-CVPH pays for you to continue your education
there is usually room for advancement
cons:
you don't get a lot of acknowledgement for the hard work you do
the rules change frequently and are inconsistent from employee to employee
most times management does not share new info with the staff or all the staff
the health coverage has a terribly high deductible
there is an option for 403b but UVM-CVPH does not contribute
UVM-CVPH can help you financially in different ways but you have to qualify for that help
although UVM-CVPH is unionized I found SEIU 1199 to be of no help to me most of the time
a stressful job effects some people negatively and you end up having to work with a cranky pants; rain, sleet snow or shine
UVM-CVPH is very HIPAA sensitive so you might want to take a HIPAA course to protect your job

pros:
Some good colleagues
good location
students
new Davis center has nice amenities
cons:
Did not cover my severance pay
Lots of infighting, very uncomfortable as management was always trying to force you to take sides
The head of the department was always disappearing from the office and handing out work for everyone else to do but he did not seem to do any work of his own.
They constantly plagiarized content, and that is really bad with professors and UVM leadership. They should be setting an example - not copying other people’s work and passing it off as their own! 
Some good ideas at times but nothing executed. The computer science enterprise division is among the worst! They wanted credit for other people’s work but don’t do much themselves, are super negative and critical of everyone. Very strange atmosphere, and they seemed to forget they work for the university and students, not for their own private agenda! Unfortunately that is how a lot of UVM works. How any of these people got hired is impossible to understand!

review_title: Though staff salaries have been stagnant, you otherwise find a high degree of respect from management.
job_title: Student Support Generalist in Burlington, VT
pros: Respect from my supervisor and a high degree of autonomy are among the best reasons to work here. The campus environment is one of high student activism, and I like that, too.
cons: Salaries haven't changed for staff for nearly a decade. Meanwhile, faculty and top administrators continue to get great raises. Good for them, bad for us. There are actually two staff union movements going on campus right now. Though I've never really cared about union activity before, I'm hoping that one of the movements gets made official so that we can bargain for higher wages.

pros: University of Vermont is placed in beautiful state of Vermont. The group that I work with, includes some awesome, supportive, hardworking people that working with them is really a great opportunity for me. I learned a lot from them and still learning and they push me toward my limits. They are really enthusiastic about power grids that makes everyone enthusiastic. You can really see "Team Work" in power system group of UVM. if I want to say some keywords for Pros I should say : smart, hard working, supportive, caring
cons: There are not lots of industrial company in state of Vermont which makes it hard for finding internship. Engineering department is also relatively small.

review_title: Great if you're planning on living in VT for a bit.  Good benfits and relaxing working environments.
pros: Benefits and free tuition.  The University of Vermont has a great attitude towards going "green".  I think that eventually UVM will become one of the Most Desired Schools to go to in the New England region.  The people that the University of Vermont employs are diversed.  I believe the trend for the University is to increase diversity to its staff, faculty, and students.  This includes minorities and gays and lesbians.
cons: Low wages and parking is a HUGE issue.  A lot of the students have a hard time finding parking spots and tend to take up spots in the faculty lots.  It is an ongoing battle to find adequate parking at the University of Vermont.

review_title: Okay for the short term, but not a place for a career
job_title: Laboratory Research Technician in Burlington, VT
pros:
- Can take up to 15 credits worth of classes for free every year
- Good health coverage and dental plan
- Beautiful location
cons:
- Virtually no opportunity for career advancement
- Human resources department is disorganized and rude. Employees constantly must fight with HR to correct mistakes made to benefits, paychecks, taxes withheld, etc.
- Salary is very low for the level of education, experience and expertise required for most positions
- Overall disgruntled atmosphere among faculty and staff
- Very little parking, and can be very expensive to get an employee parking pass, depending on where you are located on campus. Most employees have a 15-20 minute walk from their car to their job location, which can be unpleasant during the winter months.
- Very heavy on the personal and inter-departmental politics

review_title: Tale of a former work study student.
pros: I was a work study student in the Living and Learning buildings. It was a really great work environment. I was able to network with faculty and other students in buildings on campus I would not have otherwise spent a lot of time. I was able to complete assignments for my classes while at the same time gaining valuable work experience.
cons: It was hard to find a work study job after the first week or two of classes. I was not able to keep my job at the main desk because there were not any available hours that fit in my schedule with my other job.

review_title: Good place for research, exciting city in which to live.
pros: Research is promoted by administration that is helpful - IRB works with scientists to get research approved, for example. Very fast turnaround on IRB proposals, requests for technology access, and just simply great service when you need it.
cons: Budgetary constraints have handcuffed research in odd ways. Specifically it is difficult to get updated computers - I use my own laptop as the early 2000s era Mac in my office can't run a spreadsheet large enough for my data, let alone a more sophisticated statistical package.

review_title: Great benefits, but not applied equally; lots of personal politics
pros: Free tuition for up to 15 credits per year, great benefits, UVM understands the work-life balance & will help maintain it, friendly people, my department is more generous than most with the raises
cons: Administrative headaches, different systems run by different departments with lots of overlap, free tuition benefits are not accessible to everyone equally, poor salaries, I've seen people dressed down on a very personal level by some overreaching higher-ups

pros: Amazing staff! I worked in Harris Millis with the best possible staff a guy could ask for. I also was answering to a fantastic RD.
cons: Training program was a little long, but it does give you an excellent bonding opportunity with your staff. It is frustrating having to stay behind an extra day to close up the dorms during some of the breaks, but it isn't a problem if you like your team.

job_title: Research Project Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: By far the greatest benefit of working at UVM is the tuition remission. I've taken several courses during my time here and even received some graduate credit. This is an incredible benefit. If you are looking to go back to school or advance your education this is a great place to work.
cons: The pay is very low considering the workload and the cost of living (especially housing) in this area. There is very little opportunity for advancement.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: Burlington is wonderful city to live in and UVM is a respected institution in many academic areas, particularly a leader in environmental issues.
cons: As with most universities, job openings in the specific area that you are searching may be hard to come by. Vermont is not a very populated state, which compounds the problem. A lack of diversity in the population is also an issue, though it is something that the administration is working to improve.

pros: Work is very flexible, and fun. Very nice laid back community to work for.  A lot of independent work with very little supervision, and great appreciation.
cons: There is poor pay and coverage for temporary employees.  Temp. teachers are often left stranded, and kept as temps. so that the university does not have to give them benefits and a good wage.

pros:
--Flexible work schedule
--Professional autonomy
--Varied scope of engaging and challenging work (ranging from teaching graduate courses in education, mentoring literacy coaches, offering workshops/presentations on a variety of literacy topics, consulting in schools and working directly with teachers and students)
--Satisfying and rewarding to participate in such important outreach work in schools across the state of Vermont
cons:
--Grant funded so no job security from year to year
--Low salary
--Minimal and some years no funds for professional development 
--Professional isolation: VRI consultants work alone out in schools and have little sense of a professional community and support
--Organization lacks clear mission, governance structure, and leadership

review_title: It was some of the best training in my field I have ever had.
pros: Good training in research, especially in how to run a lab from the ground up.  After training here you can start a lab anywhere, knowing the basics of what you need.
cons: Faculty not as friendly as they could be and this caused some issues with publications and work load.  Other universities place an emphasis on publishing while this one places an emphasis on you working and publishing after you are done here.

pros: The staff are committed and willing to do anything it takes for the students.
cons: Administration, Provosts, and Directors are so focused on their own upward mobility and fitting in to the oppressive culture that they mistreat and misrepresent staff. This is in multiple departments.  When asked for support in dealing with manipulation, power hoarding, and being undermine I was told I had to pay for my own mediator or just not deal with it. I write this as a cautionary tale for those that think UVM is an amazing employer. There are other places that you will be acknowledged and appreciated for your talents.

review_title: UVM values diversity and an inclusive culture.
pros: A great place to work. They have a great benefits package with great health insurance, tuition remission, and a commitment to a healthy work-life balance. The people at the university and greater community are caring and supportive.  Burlington, Vermont is one of the best small cities in the US offering clean air, great schools, a diverse community and has a good venue supporting the arts.
cons: There are no cons as far as I am concerned.

review_title: Good graduate school for certain specialties
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: Gorgeous campus and resources. Professors in some fields are top-notch. Access to computing resources makes research easier.  Great work-life balance. Great school for health-care, complex systems, evolutionary robotics and data mining.
cons: Small number of faculty and graduate students in the engineering, computer science, and mathematics department. While the faculty in some specializations was great, there were major gaps and variation in the quality of professors.

pros: Large community, great place to meet new people and interact with like-minded individuals. Located about a mile from downtown Burlington which is a HUGE plus. The University offers lots of opportunities to explore your interests and pursue different career options.
cons: High turnover rate, difficult to be in a management role as there are constantly new faces to be trained. Small pay, can be a very stressful position. Required to return exams to professors, very unpleasant in bad weather.

review_title: Extremely positive practical experience, limited by my need for full-time employment
pros: I had really fantastic supervisors and I was able to gain more responsibility and skills throughout my four years working part-time during my undergrad
cons: The office I worked for tends to keep employees unsalaried and just below full-time, making me feel pressured to move somewhere with more security. They can also be a VERY high-stress environment, but they work to create some work-life balance.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: Full tuition and expenses for the entire summer and school year. Biweekly stipend for rent, food, and other costs.  Very friendly staff.
cons: Professors are hard to reach and meet with. They  seem to always be busy and have minimal office hours. The facilities such as the electronics labs are outdated.

review_title: Clean things house and modernize, or slowly rot
pros: location. location. location.  Steady employment.
cons: Very troubled university, financially and culturally. Administrators have failed. Academia is tough because of tenure entrenchment finding its way into management of the university.  Things get swept under the rug. It will die a slow death at this rate. Even the administrators admit it off the record, but they know they're part of the problem.

review_title: Low Pay, Bad Management and Lots of In-Fighting
pros:
Burlington is a great community!
Great students
Computer department staff (depot) on main campus are very helpful
Great athletics
Healthy living
Nice greenhouses
Beautiful area (Vermont itself)
cons:
department of plant and soil sciences is very badly run
lots of infighting
very low pay (below national average) and too low to live in Vermont (as rent is high)
nothing gets done
bad and non-existent leadership
lot of internal politics
favoritism
cronyism
professors and faculty are more obsessed with their own interests than running a good program for the students
tenured professors that have outlasted their value
not enough clinical or scientific process
not professional standards
not enough cleanliness maintained in labs and buildings

review_title: Not a bad place to live but not exactly a world-class institution.
pros: Absolutely gorgeous location and a lively undergraduate student body.  The people are very pleasant and the campus is located downtown.
cons: Very isolating from the international community and not a huge depth of expertise on campus in particular fields.  If you want to study agriculture, then UVM has a lot of advantages but other than that it wasn't up my alley.

job_title: Digital Art Lab Monitor in Burlington, VT
pros: UVM is a gentle place filled with supportive, thoughtful people. Everyone is very pleasant and friendly.
cons: It is very politically correct. This is not a bad thing per say, but sometimes they force it down your throat a bit. It's a very open and welcoming environment nonetheless.

pros: Forward thinking environment, lots of research opportunities.  Great place to foster relationships and form a professional network.
cons: Unfortunately due to the fact that it is a university the pay is less than if one were to be found in the industry itself.

pros: Great location for after-research activities and amazing scenery. Great Graduate Student Senate that provides for an array of social and professional development workshops.
cons: Depending on funding sources & adviser , you're pretty much working around the clock to push results and keep money coming in. In addition, there are very few scholarships so your stipend gets bled dry very fast if you're not too careful with Burlington's expenses.

review_title: GIS Technician at Spatial Analysis Lab
pros: I worked in the Spatial Analysis Lab at Aiken Center and it was great! The atmosphere was fun and relaxed. The manager and director care about everyone and help you learn more and move into more advance projects if you ask. Plus the flexible hours are awesome!
cons: Sometimes the work got a bit boring but you can listen to audiobooks or music

review_title: It was a great learning experience but not a career
pros:
location
colleagues
experience
fresh
green 
environmental
research oriented
i had the opportunity to work with numerous individuals from various backgrounds
cons:
the salary range was less than ideal as there were limited other opportunities within the area.
Management was not always in tune with the staff's needs

review_title: All around a very good job during college
job_title: Supplemental Instruction Leader in Burlington, VT
pros: Working in the Center for Academic Success was a very positive and rewarding experience. The supervisors were extremely helpful and ready to answer any question, big or small. It was very easy to schedule around my classes because I got to pick my own hours.
cons: You won't work more than 10 hours a week being a SI leader.

pros: People are friendly and outgoing. The teachers are somewhat accessible. Overall, UVM is what you make of it. Join a lab, or find a way to get involved.
cons: Not very competitive. Doesn't stand out on your resume. Hard to find a job afterwords. You have to seek extra help if you need it. Classes are usually big your first 2-3 years.

review_title: Supportive, caring colleagues and supervisors that are dedicated to helping students.
pros:
VT is beautiful and people there are super friendly. 
Students are great to work with. 
Great benefits: health, investment accounts and many paid holidays. 
Strong  commitment to diversity training/edu.
cons: Little room to grow from counselor to management positions since department is small.

job_title: Student Admissions Representative in Burlington, VT
pros: Really strong community. The Admissions counselors treated the student representatives with respect and not like children. I gained valuable communication skills. Even such a specific role in admissions there was room for advancement.
cons: The time frame is very specific which excludes a lot of students from applying and can limit employees class selection.

pros: Really enjoyed being a teaching assistant in the environmental program, I held the position for both ENVS 001 and 002. The independence for curriculum design in the labs was a great skill set to attain while still a student.
cons: I suppose there were times where it was unclear how to maintain consistency when grading labs, as different TAs evaluated the labs differently.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: Real life experience, Great experience to have under your belt before graduation. Get to work on cutting edge technology
cons: Some of the work seemed pointless and the hours were up to you to track and have people approve.

pros: The library is in the center of campus making it a very convenient location for students with lots of classes. You can use a computer during your shift, allowing you to complete other work while working at the front desk. Hours are very flexible, you can work as much or as little as you want.
cons: No significant cons to mention

review_title: UVM is decent place to work
pros: Good and convenient place to work for students.  Staff is generally nice.  Depending on position, there are lots of opportunities to meet other students.  Laid back atmosphere.  Some jobs allow workers to listen to music.
cons: The pay is not good (which is probably expected).  Not much room for advancement.

pros: Allowed me to experience an academic research position, helped me develop critical time management skills. Allowed me to develop laboratory technique
cons: Was expected to work for long stretches of time (multiple weeks) without a day off. Work Life balance was difficult

pros:
Professors and faculty in Complex Systems Center are all fantastic human beings with a passion for exploring interesting social spheres using the tools associated with big data. 
Beautiful campus and surrounding local scene on the Burlington waterfront.
cons: Undergraduate population can make campus feel like college again. No major Cons to share here.

pros: great environment and beautiful place to live.
cons: not very diverse. hard to park and the living expense is high.

review_title: Great place to enter the sports world
pros: Tight nit community with both staff and students. Everyone is very approachable and open to providing help. For people interested in getting involved in sports this is a great place to have high visibility and responsibility early in your career.
cons: It is a smaller athletic department which has budgeting downsides.

pros: Vermont is a good reason to work here. Great colleagues and the environment at the college of medicine is very collaborative.
cons: Small university. Not much money in terms of endowments. Tenure at the college of medicine is almost impossible to get unless you are an MD. The institutional support for research is not very strong.

pros: It's a university. Job security is all-but guaranteed. The benefits package is extremely good if you manage to stick around for five or more years.
cons: You are generally not going to get the same salary that you could elsewhere. If you are a top performer, you might get frustrated with that.

job_title: Wood Shop Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: The wood shop supervisor is the most awesome guy. Super lenient, personable, compassionate, understands that you have your own work to do, will let you work on your own projects when you are not on the job and there isn’t another class going on.
cons: I have no complaints about this position.

pros: Beautiful and unique location. Good benefits package. The university is one of the most green in the country.  Good students and staff to collaborate with.
cons: Overcrowded city with no parking, terrible weather, and limited opportunities elsewhere. Low salary for level of education, and high living costs.

pros: I learned a lot in this university and the city is so beautiful. Nice people here. Nice place. I have taken several courses during my time.
cons: The pay is very low considering the workload and the cost of living. The rental is expensive compare to other place and the tuition is high.

pros: There are good students to work with, good administrative support from the university, and excellent library and course creation support.
cons: The university does not recognize adequately achievement on the part of adjunct lecturers, and is far more focussed on research funding than teaching. Good teaching is not rewarded either financially or contractually.

review_title: UVM was one of the most exhilarating experiences where I grew professionally as well as personally.
pros: What I loved the most about this job was being able to connect with different students in a professional level.
cons: I have no negative comments. My supervisor was very pleasant and encouraging.

review_title: Clinical Research Center was a great place to work as a student
pros: The research team for the ABCD Study were all friendly and easy to work with. Diverse group of participants. The clinical research center at the UVM Medical Center is very nice.
cons: Limited amount of hours per week.

job_title: Graduate Student Teaching Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: Great mentors for research. Graduate teaching assistant stipend was not much to live on, but you can easily make it work if you live in the right place and are somewhat frugal.
cons: Graduate level coursework was not nearly as rigorous as I would hope.

job_title: Business Support Generalist in Burlington, VT
pros: Academic environment. Great co-workers. Benefits. Autonomy. Work/Life balance. I can't speak for other programs though - they vary according to each department's staff.
cons: Low salary. Long wait for parking permit. No staff union

review_title: The supervisor and the team makes or breaks the experience.
pros:
Amazing variety of supervisors and a good work environment  for all the residential advisers . 
The support given by the Residential life team is amazing.
cons: They must practice what they preach

pros: Vermont is a utopia compared to other us states
cons: It may be hard if your black- in that Vermont is 98% white. I'm brown, so I stood out... But I know most the people I met thought "what is he?".

review_title: Rewarding place to provide support to all types of learners (undergrad, continuing education, medical, ms, phd students)
pros: Staff Benefits! Classes for free, great health insurance, retirement contribution, progressive time off, potential for work-hour flexibility.
cons: Limited upward mobility for staff within units.

pros: Faculty are dedicated and great to work with.  Staff is very helpful and friendly.
cons: Departments tend to be small and close knit (can be good or bad).  Wages are good for the area but not competitive with other large universities.

pros: Great colleagues, and, at least in my department, interesting work that is constantly evolving.
cons: Bureaucratic structure in terms of contracting with other organizations, being paid mileage, and other administrative pieces can be frustrating--lots of forms to fill out that are constantly changing.

pros: Great people, common goals, hard working
cons: The union did nothing but hold me back personally

job_title: Registered Nurse in South Burlington, VT
pros: Great benefits and other health care workers
cons: Large corporation with little empathy for my mother's health issues and the fact I needed to assist in her recovery missing time.

job_title: Work Study Position in Burlington, VT
pros: I had a great experience in my work study position. Awesome manager, flexible hours, and nice coworkers. It was a great experience for a work study job.
cons: Low hourly wage, boring work.

pros: I had a good time at UVM as a teaching assistant. As a graduate student myself, I learned a lot during the course of teaching.
cons: The incentives is not that good despite being in an expensive city.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: Peace and safe campus. Very nice faculties and staffs. Perfect place to live and work.
cons: It's a small research university, so for each research area, there may be only one faculty.

pros:
Tuition remission benefits 
401K matching
cons:
Limited advancement opps
Salaries for staff and non-faculty are low and we have not received a raise in over 3 years.  This is not the case for faculty/administration.

pros: Excellent benefits package. Good communication among team and management.
cons: We get lower salary compared to the market but that's because we get a lot more through benefits (free tuition, 403b contribution, etc)

job_title: Lab Teacher's Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros:
Professors are eager for help and are generally very good at imparting the importance and principles behind any given project.
*Experience with vary based on lab
cons:
Pay-role seemed unnecessarily complex.
*Experience with vary based on lab

job_title: Assistant Production Manager in Burlington, VT
pros: Easy money, lots of job opportunities, and the people in charge are flexible about hours
cons: Depending on the type of job, hours can be scarce as the University tries to hire as many people as possible.

pros: Met wonderful people, learned a lot about myself, provided room and board
cons: Weekly meetings had a set time amount (3 hours) so sometimes they would drag on without reason, you lived at work

review_title: An experience that improved my education and helped hone my skills
pros: I enjoyed TAing at UVM because it helped me enrich my education while earning some money on the side.
cons: TAing was like taking on another class.

review_title: University of Vermont Athletic internship has been a great learning experience
pros:
-Can receive class credit
-Work with a great team
-Build your resume
cons:
-Not always a lot of tasks to accomplish
-Can be boring at times

pros: Nice area, social justice atmosphere and many interesting on-campus events.
cons: Extremely hard to feel welcomed and able to contribute. Lots of politics, lack of inter-office relationships and terrible technology.

review_title: Love the environment, hate the politics
pros: Great people, lovely campus, honestly would work here just for the people
cons: Lots of politics, deans and presidents do not like people outside of faculty.

pros: Great working environment, flexible scheduling with classes.
cons: Low-level tech support/troubleshooting can be a bit boring at times (just part of the job)

review_title: Great place to live, mediocre university
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros:
- Great location and high quality of life
- People are kind and friendly
- Good work/life balence
cons:
- Does not attract most talented students/faculty
- Very small

pros: I have no complaints about working for UVM. The benefits were excellent and I was paid a reasonable wage.
cons: Units don't work well together.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: Really wonderful intellectual environment, limitless opportunity for those with ambition.
cons: Not a salary that allows for independent life as an adult.  Old model, decades-old wages.

review_title: High quality education and research experience
pros:
Beautiful campus, close to downtown and waterfront.
Lot of potential for collaboration and growth.
cons: Feels kind of isolated, no career progress incentives

pros: Establishment is committed to social justice and ethics. Great work/life balance.
cons: Compensation can be lower than industry/area. Studying/Professional development not always available.

pros: Small company with lots of potential to create coatings that are natural, environmentally friendly, and durable.
cons: Money should be flowing in the doors, but for some reason its not.  Good ideas, good people, bad structure and unwillingness to accept change and drive the company to where it needs to be. No benefits offered.

pros: Great place to work with awesome benefits
cons: I don't have any

pros: The people with whom I worked were brilliant and inspiring.
cons: The University model seems to function on a basis of underpaying staff and adjuncts.

pros: Natural Resources emphasis, interdisciplinary, progressive, Vermont, R1
cons: I'm not sure that benefits for graduate students are as strong as they could be

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: Friendly professors and administrators. Good mix of people
cons: Same as with all academia, lots of red tape and unnecessary hoops to jump

review_title: Great environment, collaborative, surely depends on your department
pros: It's a very inclusive and collaborative environment
cons: Certain principal investigators are more demanding and less understanding

pros: great compensation, fun job, really enjoyed working for them.
cons: none, it was an awesome experience overall.

pros:
Great vacation and health benefits
good culturee for career growth
cons:
Lack of structure
Average salar and /wages

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: Smaller city and community, lots of good outdoor activities.
cons: Extremely left leaning and dangerous to oppose held viewpoints.

review_title: Good place to get your graduate degree
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: It has a great graduate school program!
cons: I cannot think of any cons.

job_title: Assistant Director/Program Director in Charlotte, NC
pros: Working hard to ensure diverse student and staff.
cons: -sometimes not in touch with staff

pros: Decent pay. Wonderful location and events.
cons: Sometimes it can be hard to get in tough with people

pros: good environment, calm and quite place for doing research
cons: Not a big networking opportunities, limited options for career building

job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Burlington, VT
pros: Great work environment, students, benefits, location
cons: UVM offers relatively low pay for student services.

pros: They pay biweekly and good
cons: They had budget concerns for COVID and cancelled all student employment

pros: Great biology department. Lots of interesting research. Learned a lot working here.
cons: I didn't have any cons.

review_title: Great  environment and experience  but underpaid
pros: lots of opportunities and great location
cons: underpays researchers and not great benefits

pros: Great colleagues, adjustable hours and interesting events
cons: Physically demanding, some unprofessional behavior from other student employees.

pros: Easy and convenient work while in school.
cons: Huge bureaucracy, accounting department issues.

pros: Friendly environment, Beautiful scenery in Burlington
cons: Its pretty rural and cold in Vermont

pros:
Meet people of all backgrounds
Satisfying work
cons: Possible inefficient in its management style

pros: feel like my voice was heard
cons: Very large overall company

pros: Ability to work around my class schedule
cons: Last minute notification of when to grade

pros: Beautiful scenery and people a very friendly.
cons: Cold and snowy in the winter.

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros: Very friendly environment. you will enjoy working there
cons: actually, I can not say anything

pros: good benefits ,study .health assurance
cons: nothing bad instead of low pay

pros: Excellent work-life balance; Great independence
cons: Leadership is not well-versed in growth patterns for all trajectories

pros: Great people and easy work
cons: Not great benefits , upper management disconnect

pros: Great coworkers and work environment!!
cons: I barely make more than minimum wage

job_title: Operations and Outreach Administrator in Burlington, VT
pros: benefits, staff, students, campus, faculty
cons: limited mobility, cold, limited negotiations

pros: benefits, location, working environment, flexible schedule
cons: disorganized, not stable position, lack of management,

pros: Solid compensation, easy work, flexible hours
cons: Not satisfying or growth-orientated, not motivating

pros: Vermont is a great location.
cons: Inability to progress, lackluster management.

job_title: Nurse Practitioner, Faculty in Burlington, VT
pros: academically stimulating, great benefits, good people
cons: low salary, lack of diversity

pros: Top rated University. Beautiful location.
cons: Salaries are low. Communication is poor.

pros: Can make my own hours
cons: The University does not pay enough.

pros: just for learning custodial service houssekiping
cons: absences and lack of cooperation in labor and lax

pros: paid time off was great, location was nice
cons: low pay, no internal promotions, policies were not evenly adhered to between departments
